metadata.title: Under the Greenwood Tree
metadata.subject: English
metadata.description: A song by William Shakespeare from the play 'As You Like It'. The song invites those who have given up ambition and worldly pursuits to come live a simple, free life in the forest, singing to the birds, with no enemy but winter and rough weather.

preAssessment.question: From which play is the song 'Under the Greenwood Tree' taken?
What does the old English word 'hither' mean?
Who is invited in the song to come under the greenwood tree?
options: B) Those who have given up ambition

preAssessment.question: According to the song, what is the only enemy in the greenwood forest life?

concepts.title: Shakespeare and 'As You Like It'
concepts.content: William Shakespeare (1564‚Äì1616) is widely considered the greatest writer in the English language. He wrote 37 plays, 154 sonnets, and many poems. 'As You Like It' is one of his famous comedies, written around 1599. The play is set partly in the Forest of Arden, a magical place where characters who have been unfairly treated in court (real life) escape to live freely and honestly. 'Under the Greenwood Tree' is a song sung in this play by a character named Amiens. The song captures the play's central idea: the simple, free forest life is more joyful and honest than the complicated, corrupt life at court with all its ambition, politics, and competition.
examples: Shakespeare's plays are performed all over the world ‚Äî in London's Globe Theatre, in Mumbai's Prithvi Theatre, and in schools across Maharashtra.
'As You Like It' is a comedy ‚Äî it has misunderstandings, disguises, and a happy ending, unlike his tragedies like Hamlet.
The Forest of Arden in the play represents a place of freedom and honest living ‚Äî like India's forest ashrams where saints lived simply.
keyPoints: William Shakespeare (1564‚Äì1616) ‚Äî greatest English writer, wrote 37 plays
'As You Like It' is a comedy set partly in the Forest of Arden
The forest = freedom from ambition, politics, and corruption
'Under the Greenwood Tree' is sung by character Amiens in the play
The song expresses the play's theme: simple life > ambitious worldly life
concepts.funFact: William Shakespeare was born and died on the same date ‚Äî April 23rd! He was born on April 23, 1564 and died on April 23, 1616. April 23 is now celebrated as World Book Day in his honour!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Meaning of the Song
concepts.content: The song invites people to come under the greenwood tree (a large, shady tree in the forest) and sing along with the sweet bird's throat ‚Äî meaning to sing as freely and naturally as birds do. The singer says: here, there is no enemy except winter and rough weather. This means: in the forest, the only challenges are natural ones like cold and storms. There are no human enemies ‚Äî no jealousy, competition, backstabbing, false friends, or political rivals. The song paints a picture of a paradise where life is simple, honest, and free. The repeated invitation 'Come hither, come hither, come hither!' (Come here!) is a warm, enthusiastic call to anyone who is tired of the world's complications.
examples: Like a picnic in the forest ‚Äî no homework, no competition, just enjoying nature and singing together.
The 'sweet bird's throat' is a beautiful way of saying ‚Äî sing as freely as a bird, without self-consciousness.
In India, saints like Tukaram and Kabir also preferred simple, forest-like lives over the royal court's complexities ‚Äî the same message as this song.
keyPoints: Come under the greenwood tree ‚Äî come to the forest for simple, free living
Sing to the sweet bird's throat ‚Äî sing as freely and joyfully as birds
No enemy but winter and rough weather ‚Äî no human rivalry, jealousy, or politics
Repeated 'Come hither, come hither, come hither!' ‚Äî enthusiastic, warm invitation
The song = paradise of simple living vs complicated ambitious worldly life
concepts.funFact: Many people who are stressed by city life in India go to forest retreats and eco-villages ‚Äî exactly what Shakespeare's song invites. The Forest Research Institute in Dehradun even has a beautiful campus where people can walk among ancient trees for peace of mind!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Who is Invited ‚Äî The Free Spirit
concepts.content: The song specifically invites 'who doth ambition shun' ‚Äî those who avoid or reject ambition. Ambition means a strong desire for wealth, power, or fame. The song does not invite just anyone ‚Äî it invites those who have made a conscious choice to step away from the rat race of ambition, competition, and worldly success. These are people who prefer honesty and simplicity over power and wealth. 'Doth' is the old English form of 'does'. So 'who doth ambition shun' = 'whoever avoids ambition'. The song says: if you are that kind of person ‚Äî free-spirited, content, preferring a simple life ‚Äî then come, this forest is for you. The forest is a place for those who are free in spirit.
examples: A person who leaves a high-paying city job to become a farmer or teacher in a village ‚Äî they 'shun ambition' and prefer a simpler life.
India's Vanprastha tradition (third stage of life in Hinduism) where people leave worldly life for the forest ‚Äî the same spirit as this song.
Mahatma Gandhi gave up a successful legal career to live simply ‚Äî a real example of someone who chose to shun ambition.
keyPoints: 'Who doth ambition shun' = whoever avoids/rejects ambition (the rat race)
Ambition = strong desire for wealth, power, fame ‚Äî the song invites those who reject this
The forest is for free spirits ‚Äî people content with simple, honest living
The song does NOT say ambition is always wrong ‚Äî it invites those who CHOOSE simplicity
This is a personal invitation to those whose nature is free and content
concepts.funFact: Today, many young people worldwide are choosing 'downshifting' ‚Äî deliberately choosing less stressful, lower-income jobs to have more free time and happiness. Shakespeare described this choice 400 years ago in 'Under the Greenwood Tree'!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Old English Words in the Song
concepts.content: Shakespeare wrote around 1600 AD ‚Äî over 400 years ago. The English language has changed a great deal since then. The poem uses several Old English words that are no longer used in modern English. 'Hither' means 'here' ‚Äî 'Come hither' = 'Come here'. 'Doth' means 'does' ‚Äî 'who doth ambition shun' = 'who does shun ambition'. 'I'the' (or 'i' the) means 'in the' ‚Äî a shortened, contracted form. These old words are called archaic words. Reading archaic language helps us understand what English sounded like centuries ago, and also helps us read Shakespeare's original texts more easily. These words may look strange at first, but they are simply older forms of words we already know.
examples: 'Come hither, come hither' = 'Come here, come here' ‚Äî simple once you know the meaning.
'Who doth ambition shun' = 'Who does avoid ambition' ‚Äî 'doth' is just the old form of 'does'.
Like how Marathi has changed over centuries ‚Äî old Marathi texts use different forms of words that are not used in modern Marathi.
keyPoints: 'Hither' = here (old English)
'Doth' = does (old English)
'I'the' = in the (old contraction)
These are called archaic words ‚Äî no longer in common use
Shakespeare's language is 400+ years old, so many words look unfamiliar today
concepts.funFact: Many archaic English words are still used in legal documents in India! Words like 'hereby', 'therein', 'aforesaid' in legal contracts are old English words similar to 'hither' and 'doth' ‚Äî old-fashioned formal English preserved in law!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Theme ‚Äî Simple Life vs Ambition
concepts.content: The central theme of the song is the contrast between two kinds of life: (1) The ambitious, worldly life ‚Äî full of competition, political games, greed, jealousy, and enemies. (2) The simple, natural life in the forest ‚Äî free, honest, peaceful, with only nature's challenges (winter, rough weather). Shakespeare uses the greenwood tree as a symbol of freedom and natural happiness. The song suggests that true contentment comes not from wealth or power, but from living simply and honestly, in harmony with nature. This theme connects with many Indian philosophical traditions ‚Äî the idea that the 'material world' causes suffering, and simplicity brings peace. The forest represents moksha (liberation) from the cycle of worldly competition.
examples: In the Ramayana, Ram chooses to live in the forest (vanavasa) where his life becomes purer and more heroic than it was in the palace.
India's tribal communities who live in forests and have very few material possessions often report high levels of contentment and community happiness.
The 'Slow Life' movement in modern India encourages people to leave busy cities for quieter, simpler village or forest lifestyles.
keyPoints: Theme: Simple, natural life > ambitious, competitive worldly life
Greenwood tree = symbol of freedom, contentment, natural happiness
Worldly life has human enemies; forest life has only natural ones (winter, weather)
Connects with Indian philosophy: material world causes stress; simplicity brings peace
The song is an invitation to choose inner freedom over outer success
concepts.funFact: The concept of 'Thoreau's Walden' ‚Äî a famous American author who went to live alone in the forest for two years to simplify his life ‚Äî is exactly the experience Shakespeare sings about. People across centuries and cultures have longed for this greenwood tree life!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

test.question: Who wrote the song 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
test.explanation: William Shakespeare wrote 'Under the Greenwood Tree'. It is a song from his famous comedy 'As You Like It', written around 1599.

test.question: From which play is 'Under the Greenwood Tree' taken?
test.explanation: 'Under the Greenwood Tree' is a song from Shakespeare's comedy 'As You Like It'. The play is set partly in the magical Forest of Arden.

test.question: What does the old English word 'hither' mean?
test.explanation: 'Hither' is an old English word meaning 'here'. 'Come hither' means 'Come here'. It is an archaic word no longer used in modern everyday English.

test.question: What does the old English word 'doth' mean?
test.explanation: 'Doth' is the old English form of 'does'. So 'who doth ambition shun' = 'whoever does shun ambition' in modern English.

test.question: Who is invited in the song to come under the greenwood tree?
options: B) Those who have given up worldly ambition
test.explanation: The song invites 'who doth ambition shun' ‚Äî those who have chosen to give up or avoid worldly ambition, competition, and the rat race. These are free-spirited people who prefer simple living.

test.question: According to the song, what is the only enemy in the forest life?
test.explanation: In the forest, the song says the only enemy is winter and rough weather ‚Äî natural challenges. There are no human enemies like jealousy, competition, or political rivals.

test.question: What does the song invite people to sing to?
options: A) The sound of the river
D) The wind in the trees
test.explanation: The song invites people to 'sing...unto the sweet bird's throat' ‚Äî meaning to sing as freely and naturally as birds do, in harmony with nature.

test.question: What is the main theme of 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
options: A) The importance of being ambitious and successful
B) The joys of a simple, free, natural life over a life of ambition
C) The dangers of living in the forest
D) How singing improves your voice
test.explanation: The main theme is that a simple, free life in nature is more joyful and peaceful than an ambitious, complicated worldly life. The greenwood tree symbolises freedom and natural contentment.

keyConcepts: 'As You Like It' ‚Äî comedy set in Forest of Arden
Song theme: simple forest life vs ambitious worldly life
Invited: those who shun ambition ('who doth ambition shun')
No enemy but winter and rough weather in forest life
Old English words: hither=here, doth=does, i'the=in the
Greenwood tree = symbol of freedom and contentment
commonMisconceptions: Students may think the song is against all ambition ‚Äî it simply says that SOME people choose simplicity and the song invites THEM; it doesn't condemn ambition for everyone.
Old English words look difficult but are simple once explained ‚Äî 'doth', 'hither', 'i'the' just mean 'does', 'here', 'in the'.
The forest in the song is symbolic ‚Äî it represents any life of simplicity, not literally moving to a forest.
Students may confuse 'As You Like It' with other Shakespeare plays ‚Äî it is a COMEDY (happy ending), not a tragedy.
realWorldExamples: India's forest ashrams (like those of Ramana Maharshi or Sri Aurobindo) represent exactly the greenwood tree ideal ‚Äî simple living for inner peace.
India's tribal communities in Maharashtra's Sahyadri hills live close to nature with very few material possessions ‚Äî a real-life greenwood tree existence.
The contrast of ambitious Mumbai city life vs peaceful Konkan village life is a very Maharashtra-specific example of the song's theme.
Gandhian philosophy of simple living and high thinking ('Sade jiyo, uchch vichar karo') perfectly captures the essence of this song.

interactiveElement.title: Vocabulary Flashcards!
interactiveElement.description: Flip each card to reveal the meaning of the word.

cards.back: A figure of speech comparing two unlike things without using 'like' or 'as'
Repetition of the same initial consonant sound in nearby words
A word that has the same or similar meaning as another word

cards.front: What is a 'stanza' in a poem?
cards.back: A group of lines in a poem, similar to a paragraph in prose

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: Who wrote the song 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
qaCards.answer: William Shakespeare wrote 'Under the Greenwood Tree'. It is a song from his famous comedy 'As You Like It', written around 1599.

qaCards.question: From which play is 'Under the Greenwood Tree' taken?
qaCards.answer: 'Under the Greenwood Tree' is a song from Shakespeare's comedy 'As You Like It'. The play is set partly in the magical Forest of Arden.

qaCards.question: What does the old English word 'hither' mean?
qaCards.answer: 'Hither' is an old English word meaning 'here'. 'Come hither' means 'Come here'. It is an archaic word no longer used in modern everyday English.

qaCards.question: What does the old English word 'doth' mean?
qaCards.answer: 'Doth' is the old English form of 'does'. So 'who doth ambition shun' = 'whoever does shun ambition' in modern English.

qaCards.question: Who is invited in the song to come under the greenwood tree?
qaCards.answer: The song invites 'who doth ambition shun' ‚Äî those who have chosen to give up or avoid worldly ambition, competition, and the rat race. These are free-spirited people who prefer simple living.

qaCards.question: According to the song, what is the only enemy in the forest life?
qaCards.answer: In the forest, the song says the only enemy is winter and rough weather ‚Äî natural challenges. There are no human enemies like jealousy, competition, or political rivals.

qaCards.question: What does the song invite people to sing to?
qaCards.answer: The song invites people to 'sing...unto the sweet bird's throat' ‚Äî meaning to sing as freely and naturally as birds do, in harmony with nature.

qaCards.question: What is the main theme of 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
qaCards.answer: The main theme is that a simple, free life in nature is more joyful and peaceful than an ambitious, complicated worldly life. The greenwood tree symbolises freedom and natural contentment.

longAnswers.question: Explain the main theme of the song ‚ÄúUnder the Greenwood Tree‚Äù.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The song celebrates a simple, natural, and carefree life away from greed, competition, and courtly pretence. It invites people to come into the forest and live in harmony with nature. The speaker values freedom, companionship, and contentment over material ambition. Thus, the poem presents nature as a space of emotional peace and moral clarity.
keyPoints: Theme: simple living and freedom in nature.
Rejects artificial social pressures and ambition.
Values contentment, fellowship, and natural joy.

longAnswers.question: Who is invited under the greenwood tree, and what kind of life is offered there?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The song invites anyone who is free-hearted and willing to accept life without luxury or false pride. Under the greenwood tree, one finds open air, honest living, and companionship with people who value equality and cheerfulness. The life offered is modest but meaningful, built on nature, song, and mutual goodwill.
keyPoints: Invitation is open to free-minded, non-greedy people.
Offered life is modest, cheerful, and close to nature.
Stress on equality, friendship, and inner contentment.

longAnswers.question: According to the song, what is the only enemy? Why is this significant?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The song says the only enemy is winter and rough weather, not fellow human beings. This is significant because it contrasts natural hardship with social conflict: in the forest community, people do not harm one another through jealousy or status rivalry. The line highlights an ideal world where nature may challenge the body, but society does not wound the mind.
keyPoints: Enemy is natural hardship, not human hostility.
Suggests a conflict-free and cooperative social space.
Contrasts nature‚Äôs challenge with society‚Äôs artificial cruelty.

longAnswers.question: Write a note on the symbolic meaning of the ‚Äúgreenwood tree‚Äù.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The greenwood tree symbolizes shelter, freedom, and an alternative way of life rooted in nature. It represents a democratic space where social rank is less important than character and companionship. As a poetic symbol, it also stands for renewal, freshness, and emotional healing. The repeated invitation under the tree makes it a symbol of belonging.
keyPoints: Symbol of shelter and natural freedom.
Represents equality and humane fellowship.
Suggests renewal, healing, and belonging.

longAnswers.question: How does the language of old words (like ‚Äúhither‚Äù, ‚Äúdoth‚Äù) shape the mood of the poem?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Old words such as ‚Äúhither‚Äù and ‚Äúdoth‚Äù create a musical, classical tone and connect the reader with an earlier cultural world. This diction slows the rhythm slightly and gives the song a lyrical charm suited to performance. It also reinforces the timeless quality of the poem‚Äôs message: the longing for simple and sincere life exists across ages.
keyPoints: Archaic words create classical and lyrical mood.
Language style enhances musicality of the song.
Connects timeless values to historical poetic voice.

longAnswers.question: Compare life ‚Äúunder the greenwood tree‚Äù with modern urban life.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Life under the greenwood tree is shown as slow, communal, and minimally materialistic, while modern urban life is fast, competitive, and consumption-driven. In the poem, happiness comes from nature, music, and companionship; in cities, it is often linked with career pressure and possessions. The comparison encourages readers to rethink priorities and restore balance between progress and peace of mind.
keyPoints: Greenwood life: simple, collective, nature-centered.
Urban life: fast, competitive, materially driven.
Poem invites reflection on sustainable and humane living.

longAnswers.question: Creative response: If you were invited to live under the greenwood tree, would you accept? Give reasons.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: I would accept for some time because such life offers mental peace, closeness to nature, and relief from noise and pressure. Living there would teach self-reliance, gratitude, and value of relationships without material display. However, I would also seek balance, because modern education, healthcare, and opportunities are important. So I would choose a blended life: modern responsibility with greenwood values.
keyPoints: Take clear personal position with reasons.
Mention emotional and ethical advantages of simple life.
Acknowledge practical needs of modern life.
Conclude with balanced viewpoint.
